title: CLAUDE.md
text:
This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.


This is a personal academic website for Russ Poldrack built with Quarto. The site automatically generates publication lists using the academicdb package and is deployed to GitHub Pages.





# Install dependencies (uses uv for Python package management)
uv sync

# Activate virtual environment if needed
source .venv/bin/activate



# Render the entire Quarto site (outputs to docs/ directory)
quarto render

# Preview the site locally with live reload
quarto preview

# Render a specific page
quarto render publications.qmd
quarto render index.qmd
quarto render talks.qmd



# Fix Mastodon rel="me" link after rendering (required for Mastodon verification)
python fix_mastodon_link.py







_quarto.yml: Main site configuration

Defines website structure, navbar, and output directory (docs/)
Sets HTML theme to “flatly” with custom CSS
Output directory is docs/ (for GitHub Pages deployment)






index.qmd: Home page with bio and profile information

Uses custom grid layout with rounded profile image
Links to external profiles and resources

publications.qmd: Dynamically generated publication list

Embeds Python code that reads publications from a JSON file
Reads from ~/.cache/academicdb/publications.json
Formats publications by year with author lists, titles, DOI links, and venue information
Filters out publications marked as ignored

talks.qmd: Static list of YouTube videos and talk slides





config.toml: Legacy configuration file (no longer used for publications)

Previously contained academicdb database credentials
May still contain researcher metadata

pyproject.toml: Python project dependencies

Key dependencies: quarto, quarto-cli, pygithub, pandas
Note: academicdb is listed but only used for generating the source JSON file






fix_mastodon_link.py: Post-processing script

Adds rel="me" attribute to Mastodon link in rendered HTML
Must be run after quarto render to maintain Mastodon verification
Modifies docs/index.html directly






src/poldrack_github_io/: Minimal Python package (currently just a placeholder)








Modify content in .qmd files
Run quarto render to generate HTML in docs/
Run python fix_mastodon_link.py to fix Mastodon link
Commit and push changes (GitHub Pages serves from docs/ directory)




The publications list is read from a static JSON file at ~/.cache/academicdb/publications.json. To update: 1. Update the JSON file (typically using academicdb tools externally) 2. Re-render the page:
quarto render publications.qmd





Quarto: Static site generator for technical content
Python standard library: Used for reading and formatting JSON publication data
PyGitHub: Used for GitHub integration
uv: Python package manager (replacement for pip/poetry)





Hosted on GitHub Pages
Serves from docs/ directory (configured in _quarto.yml)
Main branch is used for deployment

title: Russ Poldrack
text:
Professor of Psychology
Stanford University
Google Scholar
Wikipedia
Poldracklab website
Bluesky




I’m a cognitive neuroscientist who uses brain imaging to study how the brain gives rise to the mind. I’m also deeply interested in improving the way that science is done, by providing researchers with tools and knowledge to help them do research that is more reproducible and more transparent.
I received my BA in Psychology from Baylor University and my PhD from the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign. After doing a postdoctoral fellowship at Stanford University, I held faculty positions at Harvard Medical School, UCLA, and the University of Texas at Austin. I’m currently the Albert Ray Lang Professor and Chair of the Department of Psychology at Stanford University. You can learn more about the work that my lab does from our lab web site, poldracklab.org. We also have an online lab manual that outlines our polices and standard operating procedures, as well as my mentoring philosophy.
I am also an Associate Director for Stanford Data Science, and Director of the Center for Open and Reproducible Science.
I’ve published several books:

Statistical Thinking: Analyzing Data in an Uncertain World (Open source version available here)
Hard to Break: Why Our Brains Make Habits Stick
The New Mind Readers: What Neuroimaging Can and Cannot Reveal about Our Thoughts
Handbook of fMRI Data Analysis (with Jeanette Mumford and Tom Nichols)

I’m currently writing a living textbook on reproducible coding with AI titled Better Code, Better Science. I’m also releasing sections of this new book regularly on my Substack.
